book.title: Regular Tessellations and hyperbolic Geometry
book.subtitle: An Approach by Constructions (without Terms and Formulas)

introduction.p: We start by considering which regular tessellations can exist in the Euclidean plane and ask whether there could be other regular tessellations in other geometries. We answer this question (for the time being) with a picture in which the regular tessellations of spherical, Euclidean and hyperbolic geometry are summarized and take this as a motivation to start looking for hyperbolic geometry.

section.title: Regular Tessellations in the Euclidean Plane
section.p: A tessellation (or tiling) of the Euclidean plane is a covering of the whole plane with one or more geometric shapes, called tiles, with no overlaps an no gaps.

This (not very precise) definition is very general. The following figure shows four selected tessellations of the Euclidean plane:
The semiregular (3, 3, 4, 3, 4)-tessellation
The Cairo pentagonal tessellation
The semiregular (4, 6, 12)-tessellation

The tessellations in consist of different regular polygons. Such tessellations are called semiregular tessellations. In the Euclidean plane there are exactly eight semiregular tesselations (see for a more precise definition and a proof).
The tessellation in is called Cairo pentagonal tessellation, since it can be found on streets in Cairo and since it consists of congruent pentagons. The Cairo pentagonal tessellation is dual to the semiregular (3, 3, 4, 3, 4)-tessellation: you get it by connecting the centers of adjacent tiles in the (3, 3, 4, 3, 4)-tessellation.

section.p:
Even it is very interesting (and not easy at all) to understand tessellations in general, we will focus only on the so called regular ressellations. For this we first remember the concept of the regular n-gon. In the following n denotes a natural number greater or equal to 3.
A regular n-gon in the Euclidean plane is a ...
A regular n-tessellation of the Euclidean plane is a side-by-side covering with regular n-gons of the whole plane with no overlaps and no gaps. Side-by-side means, that every side of every regular n-gon coincides with exactly one side of another regular n-gon. For brevity we often omit the n and write regular tesselation.

introduction.p: We deal with Euclidean line reflections and recognize that these are something like the atomic building blocks of Euclidean geometry.
We define points, lines and angles in the Poincar√© model of hyperbolic geometry.
We define the circle inversion in the Euclidean plane and work out important constructions and properties of this surprising and at the same time intuitive mapping.

chapter.title: Hyperbolic line reflections, perpendicular Bisectors and Circles

introduction.p: We learn how the hyperbolic line through two hyperbolic points can be constructed by circle inversion. Then we define the reflection on a hyperbolic line - of course also with circle inversion. With the tool of hyperbolic line reflection we are then able to introduce the hyperbolic perpendicular bisector and a kind of hyperbolic distance. We use this to define hyperbolic circles and to classify them completely.
We construct the hyperbolic regular tessellations - with what has been worked out so far, this is pleasantly simple and intuitive.
We compare essential properties of spherical, Euclidean and hyperbolic geometry.
We take a look at selected aspects of the history of hyperbolic geometry.

appendix.title: Semiregular Tessellations in the Euclidean Plane

introduction.p: We show that there are exactly eight semiregular tessellations in the Euclidean plane.

appendix.title: Line Reflections are the atomic building Blocks of Euclidean Geometry

introduction.p: We show that every distance preserving map in the Euclidean plane is a product of at most three line reflections.
